resources.string: Plastic bottles, containers, plastic decorations, plastic toys

Don\'t recycle contaminated plastics: Avoid putting greasy or food-coated plastics in the recycling bin, as this can contaminate the entire batch. Separate recyclables from trash: Check your local guidelines for proper sorting of recyclables and trash.
Glass bottles, jars, containers, and other stuff made of glass

Look for bottle banks which are designated bins for glass recycling.\nThese bins are often separated by color for clear, green, and brown glass. Sometimes blue glass also goes in the green bin. Be sure to remove the lids before tossing the container in the bin. Lids can be recycled separately depending on the material.
Aluminum cans, tin cans, metal lids,\nfoil, small metal household items.

Recycle: Rinse to remove food
residue, flatten cans if possible
to save space.

Reuse: Use metal containers
for storage, and repurpose
small metal items in DIY
projects.

Newspapers, magazines, office paper
, cardboard, paper packaging
, books (without plastic covers),
envelopes (without plastic windows.).

Recycle: Ensure paper is free
from food residue or plastic
coatings. Tear large pieces into
smaller sections for easier
processing.

Reuse: Use both sides of paper
before recycling, repurpose old
newspapers for cleaning
windows or packing fragile
items.
